ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
application of some machine learning methods in the causal framework;
Key concept and assumption of causal framework
I learned about machine learning methods including decision trees, random forests, boosting, and neural nets, and about the advantages and limitations of different causal inference meta-learners.
How to think, the most important skill at Yale. How to apply machine learning methods for causal inference problems.
I learned about the fundamental problems concerning causal inference, and how ML techniques can be utilized in some of these problems.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Some of the homework assignments seemed to be written in ways that were not clear to students, and required going to office hours in order to understand what the question was asking us to do. This was frustrating but should be improved as the class is taught more and assignment questions are written more clearly / with better specificity.
I thought this course provided a good balance between theory and computational practice. I think it would be helpful if a list of important readings were collected in one document.
I think some toy examples/example code regarding different ML methods would be helpful for learning purposes.
I think that coding sessions with the class would be helpful.
Best S&Ds course I took at Yale. As good as it gets.
Data sources can be more diverse
The course has a clear structure, focusing more on causal inference in the first half of the course and ML techniques in the second part.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The TF office hours were extremely helpful. I also appreciate that Prof. Sekhon and Colleen helped connect students to form study groups.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this was an interesting and challenging S&DS elective.
Highly recommend this class to any student who wants to take S&DS seriously.
Absolutely. Must take this course if you'd like to think hard, understand effects around you and get a peek at the future we'll soon inhabit.
This is a great elective for S&DS majors.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
